Incidentally, the title "The Big Sleep" refers to death. The first third of the action makes sense as Hawks and his writers establish the basics. The scene where General Sternwood meets Marlowe is pretty strange. The General suffers from a host of maladies and stews in a hothouse. He indulges in his vices by proxy, watching his visitors drink and smoke and sweat at the same time. The mediocre Burt Reynolds crime comedy "Shamus" reversed this scene and had its equivalent character living in a freezer. Anyway, Marlowe encounters a number of sexy ladies, including statuesque Martha Vickers as the looney Sternwood daughter who tries to sit in his lap while he is standing up. There's a funny scene when Marlowe masquerades as a homosexual in Geiger's book store. He flips up his fedora brim, puts on shades, and speaks with a lisp. Later, as if to reinforce Marlowe's red-blooded nature, he visits a book store across the street and the Acme Bookstore proprietress (Dorothy Malone) lets down his hair, locks store door, and shares a bottle of rye with Marlowe while it rains outside.Hawks may have been one of the earliest American filmmakers to ridicule Hollywood conventions. In a scene where a vicious gunsel, Lash Canino (Bob Steele), questions a man (Elisha Cook Jr.) at gunpoint, he threatens to shoot him and adds, "What do you want me to do, count to three like in the movies?" B-movie cowboy actor Bob Steele is terrific in his scenes! Don't miss "The Big Sleep."

Sometimes we look at films and see them cliched. But the reason for that is that they made the breakthrough. Humphrey Bogart's portrayal of Philip Marlowe created a character that has been copied thousands of times. He is arrogant yet soft. He is formidable and vulnerable. He is tough but suffering at times. We also have one of pairings with Lauren Bacall which is dynamite. She had a sparkle like no other.
This film is often criticized because for some it is hard to follow. I didn't feel that way. Some things take effort and this one needs the audience to pay attention, and, like most works of art, they may need to be seen more than once. Also, what an amazing cast of characters. in addition to the principles, we have some of the best character actors to grace a screen. Don't miss this film.

reviews.review_title: Classic Noir Film with gritty interpretation , atmospheric settings and powerhouse filmmaking
reviews.content: Absorbing and worthy suspense film about blackmails , killings , corruption and strong intrigue . Starred by Phillip Marlowe , a two-fisted and cynical private detective operating in Los Angeles . Phillip (Humphrey Bogart at his high point in his glorious career)'s fee was £50 a day , plus expenses . Then , the toughest Shamus , Philip Marlowe , is hired by a rich family on a twisted case with unexpected consequences . As Marlowe asked by the elderly (and near death) wealthy General Sternwood to investigate an attempt at blackmail on one of his daughters . Before the complex case is over, he's seen murder, blackmail, and what might be love . He soon finds that the attempt is half hearted at best and the daughters seem to be more connected with the disappearance of strange characters . Marlowe becomes involved with the oldest daughter , a society dame called Vivian (Lauren Bacall) and her uncontrollable as well as addled sister Carmen (Mary Vickers) who seem unconcerned with disappearances , further complicating the mystery . Only General Sternwood seems concerned as mobsters and hired killers continue to appear in the path of the investigation .This first-rate and entertaining picture draws its riveting tale and power from the interaction of finely drawn roles as well as drama , emotion and moody atmosphere . This classic mystery thriller follows Raymond Chandler's book fairly closely otherwise . Twisted film Noir about murders , troubled relationships , treason , dark secrets , including an unforgettable dialog ; being based on the novel ¨Big Sleep¨ and screen-written by the prestigious William Faulkner , Leigh Brackett , Jules Furthman and the same Raymond Chandler . Eager to repeat the success of To have and have not (1944), Warner Bros. studio chief Jack L. Warner gave Howard Hawks $50,000 to purchase the rights for "The Big Sleep" ; Hawks bought the rights for $5,000 and pocketed the rest. It has a convoluted and difficult intrigue though stars can quite compensate for some far-fetched moments . It packs a good realization , an original script , haunting atmosphere , intriguing events ; for that reason madness and murder prevail . Here Bogart is extraordinary and as cool as ever ; he plays as the tough-talking P.I. , his scenes with Lauren Bacall are awesome and at their best compared to those they shared in ¨Dark passage¨ , ¨Key Largo¨ and ¨To have and to have not¨ . The couple throws in enough sparks to ignite several lighters . This was the best pairing of cynical Humphrey Bogart and sultry Lauren Bacall , a fifth film was planned several years later, but Bogart died before it could be made . Due to Humphrey Bogart's affair with co-star Lauren Bacall, his marital problems escalated during filming, and his drinking often resulted in his being unable to work. Three months after the film was finished, Bacall and Bogart were married. Exciting as well as complex film , possessing a mysterious and fascinating blend of gripping thriller , serenity , baroque suspense in which especially stands out the portentous performances , evocative cinematography in black and white by Sid Hickox and magnificent musical score by the classic Max Steiner . A pre-release adaptation run 116 minutes with 18 m. of scenes re-shot and reused in the official release . And also shown in horrible computer-colored version . This is first film version of Raymond Chandler's first novel "The Big Sleep". The second was The big sleep in 1978 by Michael Winner with Robert Mitchum , Oliver Reed , Edward Fox , Richard Todd , Richard Boone Sarah Miles and Candy Clark , this remake was released about 32 years after the original . The latter takes place in the then contemporary Britain of 1977, even though Hawks's Big sleep took place in Los Angeles in 1941 . The movie was part of a predominantly cycle of pictures adapted from novels by Raymond Chandler , especially his first four novels , such as Murder, My Sweet (1944) , The Brasher Doubloon (1947); and The Lady in the Lake (1947). It had a revival in the 1970s , the films included Marlowe, (1969), The big sleep (1978), A long goodbye (1973) and Farewell my lovely (1975) as well as Double Indemnity (1973) made for television Chandler was screenwriter on the original (1944) directed by Billy Wilder .

reviews.review_title: Big Sleeps '45 and '46 - both good in different ways.
reviews.content: I've seen The Big Sleep a number of times over the years; it's a terrific movie with witty dialogue, a classic Bogie performance, and an unlikely number of hot women throwing themselves at the middle-aged detective. The great flaw of the film is the story, which by the end is a jumbled, confused mess.I just watched the earlier version of the movie, before Lauren Bacall's agent begged the producer to add and re-shoot scenes because he was afraid the critics would trash her for her performance as they had in her previous film - or at ignore her in favor of Martha Tilton's flashy performance as the kid sister - and he wanted to see a replay of the magic of her first movie with Bogart, To Have and Have Not.The original version of the movie would, like the final version, have been a classic 40s detective movie with a great performance from Bogart and Howard Hawk's crackling direction. It also wouldn't have been said to make no sense. Since The Big Sleep is the only Raymond Chandler book whose plot holds together in the slightest, I always thought the movie didn't make sense because they were flummoxed by how to make a movie about porn and drugs without mentioning either. But that wasn't really the issue. The 1945 version spends time explaining what's going on a couple of times, drawing connections between characters and crimes. Much of this exposition is in one particular scene with the police, and it's gone from the final version. It's understandable that they cut it, as it's a major drag on the action, but its removal makes the film incoherent.While you can argue against making a detective movie no one can follow, the pace was improved (another somewhat overlong scene of Bogart searching a house was also tightened) and the film added its most memorable scene, a suggestive conversation between Bogie and Bacall that is exactly what fans of To Have and Have Not (and Bacall's agent) wanted. The end result is faster paced and even wittier than the first version.If you're only going to watch one version of this, you should certainly watch the 1946 version. But if you're a film buff, or just want to know what on earth was going on in that 1946 movie, check this one out.

I realize this is a classic but I didn't understand anything that was going on. I gave up after Bogart got beat up. If I can't follow why people are getting blackmailed, murdered, robbed, & beat up then I'm not enjoying the movie. Watching Bogart pull on his ear & the gal bite her thumb & say "your cute" over & over again was lame. Bogart is not good looking. Women in real life would not fall instantly in love with a man like him. Yuck.

reviews.review_title: a well done Hollywoodization of a classic crime novel
reviews.content: The story itself is a mystery, that becomes more of a mystery (and perhaps more frustrating) the more you think about it. Compared to this, The Maltese Falcon's story is for kids (by Dashiell Hammet, another of the prime pulp/detective novelists along with Raymond Chandler). Bogart trades his Sam Spade for Philip Marlowe, an exchange that changes only certain patterns of witty dialog, but not by much. Marlowe is investigating a blackmail on a General, who has two gorgeous, tricky daughters, one of them Carmen Sternwood (Martha Vickers, not given enough credit along with her headlining co-stars), the other Vivian Sternwood (Lauren Bacall, right in her prime). As he digs deeper into a story of murder, corruption, and romance, things may seem out of place, almost confounding, but that is Chandler for you.I have not read all of the Big Sleep, but as a Chandler admirer I always find his use of first person narrative, trademark classical cynicism, and the kind of early day brutal, almost satirical jabs at society (highs and lows) very entertaining, and of the highest caliber of writing. For the screenplay three heavyweights- Leigh Brackett (also responsible for Altman's The Long Goodbye), William Faulkner (one of the key doomed writers of the 20th century), and Jules Furthman- pump together a script that somehow keeps this kind of twisting, keen sense of narrative and humor while still making it commercial. In some ways its as much a romantic tug & pull story, with witty, strong banter going between Bogie and Bacall, as it is one of the key film noirs.But is it as gritty a film noir as some of the less expensive ones like Detour or Gun Crazy? Does that even matter? Does Chandler's sense of the darkness of the world get lost in some of the more typical classic Hollywood aspects of the film? It might for some, especially if you're a purist for the book. Director Howard Hawks, I think, brings a balance to the styles, giving his 'there's danger when there's action' statement some good grounding here. It's almost too good a kind of direction for a film like this- everything is polished and down to the line, and even in the other director's cut from 1945 this is still prevalent. But he never lets loose his actors too far or constricts them from their alluring, striking personalities. On the contrary, this really makes use of its star players so well that at times, even when you're not sure what's going on the script carries it so completely that you just love hearing Bogie and Bacall talk. There's even a sense of whimsy in many of the better scenes. If by the end you can't understand what has happened totally, you may have missed the point- it's about the twists, the style, the kind of popular edginess of the day. It's not with the clarity or humor or experimentation of a classic like the Maltese Falcon, but in its own league the Big Sleep earns its status over time as a must-see.

reviews.review_title: Howard Hawks directed classic featuring Humphrey Bogart as Philip Marlowe, Lauren Bacall
reviews.content: O.K., so no one really knows what happened in this film (e.g. the actual solution to the mystery is still being debated today, and apparently wasn't known at the time either). It's still a classic, with Humphrey Bogart as Philip Marlowe investigating a murder and a socialite's (Martha Vickers) involvement for her father (Charles Waldren). Her sister, played by Lauren Bacall, gets involved pretty deeply in the story too, which also features a quirky (redundant?) Elisha Cook Jr. performance. There's also a great scene between Bogart and Dorothy Malone in a bookstore. Directed by Howard Hawks with a William Faulkner script. Added to the National Film Registry in 1997. Bogart's Philip Marlowe is AFI's #32 hero.Part of the reason for the film's muddled plot is the fact that it was completed in 1944, and was then shelved due to Warner Bros.'s rush to get their backlog of war themed films out the door before they became dated, per the pending end of World War II. Subsequently, Hawks' earlier film with Bogie & Bacall, To Have and Have Not (1944), was released, which contained such great interplay between its two stars (who would fall in love and marry in real life), that Jack Warner decided to put this film back in production a year after primary photography had been completed. The script was spiced up and several scenes were cut and/or altered to make it even better than the original, which was never released but can be seen (if infrequently) on TCM along with a documentary detailing the changes.

reviews.review_title: The Bogie persona at it's fullest with a twist here and there
reviews.content: Humphrey Bogart, one of the biggest movie stars of the 20th century was the one and only choice to play Philip Marlowe. The great thing about him was that he didn't seem like your typical heroic figure and that puts him right at home in the seedy environment of film noir where everybody seems kind of crooked, even the police.Though he played kind of heroic figures there was always a sinister quality to him and this is played out beautifully in this movie where he seems to be most comfortable with the villains rather than the more straight-laced characters.The plot of The Big Sleep is so complicated that you are often thinking that you are being put on. Names and events are hurled at you every 2 seconds so if you only watch this movie once you will be totally lost. The most complicated character belongs to Lauren Bacall's Vivian. Marlowe is in the dark about her role up until the last 20 minutes or so and therefore it was really unbelievable that the role is played so well by Bacall (this was only her second movie).The whole movie is quite good but a little bit slow for my taste. If you have seen The Maltese Falcon it was definitely the better of the two. Still, there are those priceless moments when Marlowe goes into the Geiger bookstore and is met with the absolute hilarious line by the clerk: "What do they look like - grapefruits?" The director, Howard Hawks, was certainly an actor's director and he gave some of the best roles to among others, John Wayne, Cary Grant, Gary Cooper and of course Bogie himself. This was as far as I can remember the last time that Bogie and Hawks worked together and I think that anything that they would have done afterwards could not live up to this, so maybe it was a good choice. Hawks would die a very old man and by the the 60's his inspiration had virtually dried out (he made Rio Bravo 3 times).Had Bogart lived longer he would probably be in spoof after spoof of his undying persona and it's a bit of a disappointment that he was not very successful at playing a different character. The part of Captain Queeg in "The Caine Mutiny" is absolutely terrific and so different from Marlowe. Although, in my opinion he is the essence of 40's movies cynicism, he should have been much more than that.

Bogart directed by Howard Hawks in a Raymond Chandler adaptation had to be a winner surely? Well the purist novel fans may not be 100% satisfied but nobody can deny the class that seeps from every frame in this film. Gangsters, sluts, weasels, and a gritty (anti) hero are all visually and orally brought to magnificence by Hawks and a cast shooting from the top of the hill.Often tagged as the unfathomable masterpiece, The Big Sleep has this power that draws you into the picture to feel completely part of it, each punch and shot seems to be a part of your life. It's an incredible experience for film lovers of all ages. Humphrey Bogart is Philip Marlowe, a private investigator called in to solve a blackmail case, and that's all you need to know because you just need to observe as Marlowe lurches from scene to scene, deeper and deeper into a convoluted mire that triumphs as each scene unfolds.One of the greatest detective films ever made, directed by a genius, starring another, and as dialogue goes it has few peers. 10/10

(Glad to see that following last night's TMC showing, IMDb at last lists Sonia Darrin's sharply etched "Agnes", the unfriendly sales girl, among the cast credits, after what had been an inexplicable omission.)Alan Silver and Elizabeth Ward's excellent source book "Film Noir" goes into some detail ferreting out the strictly noir elements of this otherwise compromised private eye melodrama. Understandably, their concern is with the movie's noirish subtext and not with the film itself. Still and all, much of noir's appeal lies in its dark forebodings about the basic nature of things. Thus, the subtext here may be worth ferreting out, but that hardly compensates, in my book at least, for the movie's overall failure to live up to standards of either a noir classic or even a movie classic, despite the fabled Bogart-Bacall-Hawks collaboration. Now, there's no need to dwell on the notoriously convoluted plot, except to insist that it really does undermine the end result. Most importantly, the general incoherence drains viewer interest because of mounting difficulty in maintaining the many threads. As a result, interest in a subtext, for example, is abandoned to hardy professionals not so concerned with whether the movie succeeds as a movie. Thus, it's the characters that must sustain audience interest. However, an unusually large, and at times confusing, supporting cast is required by the screenplay meanderings. That would be okay if the characters and their actors were consistently interesting. But they're not. The trouble is that except for the two leads no one else gets much screen time. Thus, genuinely interesting characters or actors such as the general (Waldron), Carmen (Vickers), Canino (Steele), and (Agnes) Darrin, get shuttled around by the pallid likes of Mars (a badly miscast Ridgely), Ohls (Toomey), and Brody (Heydt). In short, the screenplay is not only confusing, but over-crowded, as well. True, many of the one-liners are memorable, but no one seems in charge of what they add up to.Also, I think many folks are too much in thrall to the Bogart-Bacall-Hawks mystique to notice that this is not a triumph for any of the three. Bogart's Marlowe is basically a one-note character, who spouts snappy one-liners, sees through most every ploy, and proves irresistible to anything with long hair. To me, it gets quickly tiresome, Bogie or no Bogie. At the same time, nothing shows the movie's basic flaw better than the ruinously unnecessary afternoon dalliance between Marlowe and Acme girl Malone. Not only is it awkwardly handled (Hawks), but undercuts the credibility of the Marlowe character early on. Whatever Bogart's appeal, it's not that of a matinée idol. Then there's Bacall. To her credit, she never claimed to be much of an actress. Instead, she's a presence. The trouble is that Vivian's devious nature calls for more nuance than Bacall can manage. Thus, her performance is reduced to dialogue without behavior, and an object lesson in what proves good for a career does not necessarily prove good for a movie, basic attractions or no basic attractions. Then too, I don't see much of trademark Hawks anywhere on screen. No overlapping dialogue or real snap. Looks to me like he was shackled by the screenplay and Warner's desire to employ a bevy of contract players. Then too, there's the question of final edit, which wouldn't be the first time a studio had botched a director's cut.I'm also puzzled by some of the sub-standard sets, especially the outdoor night scenes. The occasional fog serves not only as atmosphere but also masks the shabbily done backdrops. Given the name cast and director, it's surprising to me that these detractions would pass studio muster (or Hawks'). Now, none of this is to deny that the movie does have its moments. The first 15 minutes or so amounts to a gem of an opening act. The interplay between Marlowe and the mansion's assorted characters is cleverly conceived and executed. Also, there's enough boldness in the production to hint at such forbidden adult themes as drug addiction and nymphomania. As a result, Carmen Sternwood amounts to one of the most unusual characters of the Production Code 1940's, daringly brought to life by the under-rated and star-crossed Martha Vickers. Nonetheless, the sum total adds up to a disappointingly disjointed result, made more so by the caliber of the artists involved.

reviews.review_title: A Great Film-Noir Despite Hawks and Bacall
reviews.content: This is One of those. a Movie that is so Well Liked, Patronized, Slobbered Over, and so Often Hailed as "The Perfect Film-Noir", "A Great American Classic". But when such Accolades are administered, they are often Accredited to Two Things that could be argued are Misplaced.First is Lauren Bacall, the Second is Director Howard Hawks. It could also be Argued that neither Bacall nor Hawks have Anything to do with the Appeal and otherwise Sublime, Surreal Nature of this odd Film.Lauren Bacall is Overshadowed by everything in the Movie, not the least is all the other Female Characters. In Fact, it is well Known that Martha Vickers, playing the Nympho, Drug Addict, Carmen Sternwood was so Good, She Dominated the Film and most of Her Scenes were Cut so Bacall would Not be Overlooked.Howard Hawks Stiff Style and overlapping Dialog is completely Unnecessary here because the Words themselves are so Witty and Snappy, Sarcastic and Humorous, that Hawks need Not Intrude with His bit of Clunk. A Howard Hawks Movie almost always Looks Studio Bound, Fake, and Staged. It is Evident by anyone Watching this Film-Noir, must Immediately Notice the Lack of Expressionism. The Movie was entirely Shot in a Studio and on Sound Stages and boy does it Show and the Gritty and Dark Meilu of Noir are only Evident a Few Times.But Despite Hawks and Bacall almost Sinking the Thing, the Film still manages to be Great. No Doubt because of all the Interesting and Exciting Characters and the Scintillating Dialog and of course Bogart's take on the Philip Marlowe Character that Impresses.It is Marlowe, Carmen, the General, Dorothy Malone, Agnes, Arthur Gwen Geiger, Carol Lundgren, Joe Brody, the Girlie Taxi-Driver, Pete and Sydney, Eddie Marrs, Canino, Harry Jones, and even two Characters never on Screen (Owen Taylor and Sean Reagan), that everyone Remembers. Not the "Inserted Scenes" of Bacall jousting Innuendos with Bogart and Embarrassing Herself in the Casino Singing and making Silly Gestures. OK the Racehorse Scene at the restaurant is Remembered fondly but Not for Bacall but the, once again, Sexually Charged Dialog.There's plenty of Sexy Girls, a lot of Violence, and Code-Busting subtexts like Pornography, Homosexuality, a Teenage Sex and Drug Addict, that make this Film-Noir No Doubt. But all of the Edgy Things that Create this Vintage Noir treat have Little to Do with Lauren Bacall or Howard Hawks and much More from Everything and Everyone Else.

The Big Sleep is a dreary unendearing crime/film-noir, that put me to sleep.Other than a few comical lines by Bogart, the whole thing was a mess and I couldn't care less. Bacall wasn't alluring in the slightest. She would eat Bogart alive, the pairing's nonsense. Why did all these women flirt with him? Even the female taxi driver, utter nonsense. I think I was partially asleep at this point, but why did that Eddie guy run out the door knowing his own men were out there and were going to shoot him? WHY! End already I was thinking as my eyes struggled to stay open. Funny enough I was no longer tired after it ended.Vivian: So you're a private detective. I didn't know they existed, except in books, or else they were greasy little men snooping around hotel corridors. My, you're a mess, aren't you? Philip Marlowe: I'm not very tall either. Next time I'll come on stilts wear a white tie and carry a tennis racket. Vivian: I doubt if even that will help.

Howard Hawks brilliantly captured the atmosphere of Raymond Chandler's novel "The Big Sleep" in this 1946 classic that has proved to be a favorite among its fans. The film is enhanced by the adaptation of William Faulkner, Leigh Brackett and Jules Furthman. The movie has an excellent look and the music score by Max Steiner enhances what we witness on the screen.The new director's cut shows a much tighter film, although both the studio release and Mr. Hawks' version are equally excellent. The film capitalizes in the interplay between Marlowe and Vivian. As portrayed by Humphrey Bogart and Lauren Bacall, this seems to be the main reason for watching the film. However, there are small details that render the film the brilliant piece it is.The dialog is intelligent and keeps us interested in what's going on. As Bob the Moo suggested in his commentary, it helps to keep pen and paper handy because the many sub plots will get anyone confused if no attention is paid to the proceedings we are witnessing. Also, this film seems to have gotten away with murder, no pun intended, by having been given an OK by the Hays group, because the way some things are said that convey another meaning. There is a homosexual undercurrent because of the figure of Geiger, who is obviously gay, but without mentioning the fact, or drawing undue attention to what's going on.The best thing in the film is Humphrey Bogart. He is a cool Marlowe who can unravel the mystery he is investigating. The gorgeous Lauren Bacall is just as good in her cool approach to Vivian. Not only is Ms. Bacall talented, but she casts a large presence on the movie.Howard Hawks' direction got excellent performances from the cast. Dorothy Malone's book store manager, emits so much heat, she smolders the screen! The nymphet Carmen Sternwood, hitting on Marlowe at one point, and high on drugs next, is interpreted by the sexy Martha Vickers showing she had promise. Charles Waldron, Elisha Cook Jr, Charles Brown add another layer to the film's texture.The film in any of the two versions prove to be a perennial favorite of fans of this genre thanks to Mr. Hawks' understanding of the material.

reviews.review_title: Romance and thriller with Bogart and Bacall
reviews.content: Private detective Philip Marlowe (Humphrey Bogart) is hired by General Sternwood (Charles Waldron) to keep an eye on his youngest daughter Carmen (Martha Vickers) who has fallen into bad company.She has also got a mysterious and attractive sister called Vivian (Lauren Bacall).Soon there is some romance in the air and his life in danger.Howard Hawks' The Big Sleep (1946) does a fine job combining thriller with romantic feelings.The film is based on Raymond Chandler's novel from 1939).Humphrey Bogart does his detective role once again with style.He and Lauren Bacall had married each other the previous year.You can sense that in the amount of chemistry they share in their mutual scenes.Take them in the car for instance.They certainly were made for each other.John Ridgely plays Eddie Mars in the movie and he does a very nice job.And so does Peggy Knudsen as Mona Mars.Dorothy Malone is very pretty as Acme Bookstore proprietress.I enjoyed the scene between her and Bogie in the bookstore.Elisha Cook Jr. I remember from The Maltese Falcon and he does terrific job also here as Harry Jones.This really is a fine movie, a film-noir classic.Anybody who decides not to watch it because it's too old...It's your loss

A viewer would be forgiven for taking a long siesta during "The Big Sleep." It's almost two hours of tedium followed by an underwhelming ending. My recommendation: skip this one; I was disappointed and I like the genre. I could tell right away from the first scene that this film was not to my liking as the young woman threw herself at Marlowe whom she just met. Later a bookseller and the other sister threw themselves at him as well. So I was not sure what the tone of this film was, was it a fatuous noir flick, or a more serious mystery one? I guess it tries to do both, but where are the cops -- they're never around. And where is the client, the old man who is in the first scene then disappears for the rest of the film? How does he feel about all of this?Why does Marlowe even care about any of these people, is it a sense of bringing people to justice, but then he never does that, he obstructs justice and obfuscates repeatedly. Is he in love with the "good" sister, which is laughable as she is as awful or worse than the other sister. Why is the plot so convoluted and confusing? There are too many characters involved and it is impossible to keep track of them all and their motivations. Why was the bookstore emptied out? A very disappointing film that was really not worth the time to watch. It just rambles aimlessly never really connecting with the viewer. And what does the title even mean? My rating: not a classic, 3/10.P. S. I just watched some of the "Magnum P. I." episodes featuring the Luther Gillis character; these are well done detective noir tributes that are coherent and effortlessly excel when they hardly even try to, light-years ahead of "The Big Sleep".

reviews.review_title: Just A Private Dick On Another Routine Case
reviews.content: If you ask me - I'd definitely say that The Big Sleep made for quite an enjoyable, yet unintentional, parody of the Film Noir genre. It really did.I mean, (with the hilarious way that all of the babes were literally falling into Bogart's arms, over and over again, and with so many of the bad guys being bumped off, left, right and centre, for no apparent reason) I certainly couldn't take this crime film's tale of drama at face value for even a minute.I clearly saw The Big Sleep as being played strictly for laughs. And, believe me, unintentional laughs it certainly did produce.Now 70 years old, The Big Sleep is filled to overflowing with plenty of wise-cracking dialogue, and cutie-pie bantering.... And, of course, Bogart's character was so ridiculously hardboiled and always just a little too sure of himself (regardless of any imminent danger) - And that all quickly added up to a truly comical romp down "Nostalgia Lane" for me.Anyways - Here in The Big Sleep, Humphrey Bogart plays (as only he could possibly play) character Philip Marlowe, a 25-dollar-a-day gumshoe who, agreeing to take on a cut'n'dry case of blackmail, inadvertently finds himself completely caught up in a very messy and tangled web of murder, treachery and, yes, romance that, believe me, gets screwier and screwier by the minute.I honestly can't imagine how any audience (even from the 1940s) could ever take The Big Sleep's story with dead-faced seriousness - 'Cause it's not. It's a literal laugh-riot all the way.

Phillip Marlowe (Humphrey Bogart) gets involved with the Sternwood family (including Lauren Bacall) and finds himself neck-deep in murder.The plot is impossible to summarize--it's ALL over the map. They tried to adapt a great but very difficult novel and were determined to keep everything in--or as much as the censors would allow. There were drastic changes before it was released (some of the Bogart/Bacall scenes were added and the censor demanded several cuts)...but it still came out great! The movie moves at breakneck speed--you have to pay close attention to it at every moment. This movie is so incredibly convoluted it almost demands multiple viewings. I've only seen it once and I agree--I loved it but I'm still not sure what exactly happened! There are beatings, shootouts and tons of twists and turns. It's also full of the most incredible dialogue I've ever heard. Every line has double meanings and the cast speaks VERY quickly. There's also some hilarious sexual dialogue between Bogart and Bacall--listen for the lines about horses! The acting is just great. Bogart IS Marlowe--he gets the character down perfectly. Bacall is drop dead sexy and very good in a difficult role. Also her and Bogart play off each other perfectly--it's no wonder their scenes were beefed up. Actually no one is really bad in this film--that's quite an accomplishment with such a large cast.Easily one of the best film noirs ever filmed and a must see! I give this a 10.

reviews.review_title: The Big Sleep-Yawning All the Way *1/2
reviews.content: Humphrey Bogart and Lauren Bacalle teamed to make 4 films together in their illustrious careers. Guess what? Other than 1948's "Key Largo," the other 3 were first class stinkers and "The Big Sleep" is absolutely no exception.To say that the plot is muddled and confusing is to put it mildly. The guys drop like flies as the bullet flies. The film should have ended when it appeared that the first two murders had been solved. Instead, it goes on and on with more shooting and much more confusion. By the end, you don't know really who did what and it was a relief to hear those police sirens as Bogie and Lauren embraced-you knew it was the end.This film noir faded to black all right! You really have to blame Raymond Chandler's writing for this colossal bomb.

reviews.review_title: "Count three, like they do in the movies"
reviews.content: The Big Sleep is one of the best known and distinctly archetypal examples of a style of movie-making we now call "film noir". It is also notoriously hard to follow, with a plot so and labyrinthine and subtly suggestive it leaves most viewers baffled. And yet it is immensely popular, was a commercial success in its day, and has long been praised as one of the all-time classics of the form. It must have some secret.The screenplay is adapted, very faithfully I must say, from the novel by Raymond Chandler. In a book, where it's possible to chew over a story point-by-point, such complexity is quite acceptable. But Chandler's story seems staggeringly unsuitable for the movies. For a start, the intrigue does not revolve around any tangible goal or object, like the titular bird in The Maltese Falcon, a similar but far simpler work. This means rather than watching out for who's hiding what, we have to pay attention to the relationships between the characters, none of whom has any obvious reasons for helping or hindering one another. The characters themselves are numerous, with more heavies, molls and dodgy businessmen than you can shake a pistol at. And while the dialogue is sparkling with quotable quips, whenever anyone gets onto the actual subject of the investigation, it suddenly turns into gobbledegook. Bogart's going over with Joe Brody over whoever may or may not have the photos of Carmen is a veritable tongue-twister. No wonder audiences then and now were confused.So what else does The Big Sleep have to its name? Well, most importantly it has its too leading stars, Humphrey Bogart and Lauren Bacall. Bogart and Bacall were built for noir styling. They both have a hard iciness to their personae, but with easygoing charisma and a knack for delivering smart dialogue with aplomb that makes them absolutely irresistible. And between them they have chemistry to boot. Even if you didn't know they were an offscreen couple, you would still think them destined for each other on screen. It was their first pairing a few years earlier that livened up the otherwise uninteresting To Have and Have Not, where they took a few classy lines of script and made the air crackle.Standing between this stellar pair and that convoluted plot is director Howard Hawks, and this is where things get really neat. Rather than try to elucidate the story, Hawks buries it even further. At any moment which deals with the finer details of the plot, Hawks dresses up the image with shadows, movement or really whatever clutter is available. In the opening scene at Sternwood's house, the gloomy, cavernous interiors show off the old-world austerity of the place. He then makes a bizarre jungle of Sternwood's greenhouse, with bits of plant invading the foreground like tentacles. All of this is part of the atmosphere, or more precisely the trappings of film noir, and Hawks lays it on thick to immerse us in the picture's world. However, Hawks was exceedingly good at bringing individuals out of the mosaic. In the first scene between Bogart and Bacall, all the other business fades away, the sets become light and bare, and suddenly we are just looking at two people. Compare this to the scene in which Bogart finds a drugged-up Martha Vickers at Geiger's house, where Hawks places her to blend in with the lavish decoration. She is effectively part of the scenery, not a focal point as Bacall is.The upshot of all this is, we don't end up feeling as if we've been told a story as such, but we do feel we've been given an experience. When Sternwood sets the scene to Bogart, we are unlikely to pick up all he says about Regan or Geiger, but we do remember the old man's mutterings about brandy and cigars. When Bacall comes to Bogart's office, we don't recall what she has to say, but their funny telephone conversation, where Bogart pretends Bacall is his mother and Bacall pretends Bogart is her father, sticks in our minds. By all means, try and fathom what's really going on – it's a rather fun intellectual exercise for repeated viewings – but the real point of The Big Sleep is to give us the very essence of hard-boiled fiction, of mean-faced hit men and double-crossing dames. It's nifty.

Private detective Philip Marlowe (Humphrey Bogart) is hired by a rich family. Before the complex case is over, he has seen murder, blackmail, and what might be love.Never mind that I am not a big fan of Lauren Bacall. And never mind the connections between this film and "The Big Lebowski" (which may or may not be obvious). This is the essential detective film -- of all the private eye movies, this could be the greatest, even outshining Bogart's "Maltese Falcon".The film's biggest (and possibly only) flaw is that it is not very linear, and I had trouble keeping characters straight in the first half. A second viewing would solve this, and may be something I opt to do (it would be worth it). There also exists another cut of the film with less Bacall and a more direct story. I have not seen it, but I almost wonder if this would be better... or would it kill the charm?

I don't see how so many people can rate this film so highly, when it is all but impossible to follow who is who and who did what where and when, less yet why. My mom and I watched it last night, and found it very disappointing. Watching films mostly for the sake of seeing some of the "greats" acting just isn't enough reason to spend 115 minutes looking at a television set. Once was enough, I'd never waste my time seeing the film again.Now for starters, don't make the mistake of assuming we have a problem with black-and-white, I've got dozens of non-color films in my library. But how can you follow who all of the characters are, what their motivations are, why certain people who fall into the big sleep, do that? Why did the "little man" have to be poisoned, and what sort of poison is so powerful it puts you into the big sleep in less than a minute? Why does Bogart keep pulling on his ear all of them time? Why is it that nearly every woman in the film flirts with Bogart the way they do? Sadly, when I began writing this, I had said all I wanted to say, and found I could not submit for lack of enough lines. Making enough was a challenge, as there isn't much more to say, to me, than that I just can't see how anyone follows the film and understands a story in it.

reviews.review_title: Complicated, but oh, what a movie
reviews.content: Humphrey Bogart and Lauren Bacall star in "The Big Sleep," a 1946 film which also features Martha Vickers, Regis Toomey, John Ridgeley, and Elisha Cook, Jr. Briskly directed by Howard Hawks, this film has more characters and more plots going on than can ever be described here. A rare book dealer, blackmail, murder, payoffs, a missing chauffeur, a missing wife - yikes! The story is so convoluted that the script writers had to call Raymond Chandler, on whose novel the film is based, to ask him who killed a particular character. Chandler says it's in the book, but the writers couldn't find it. So in the general release film, we're left not knowing, although the cut shown to serviceman does resolve the question. But somehow, it doesn't matter because of the casting.Humphrey Bogart is terrific as Sam Spade, absolute perfection. He mines the humor in the character as well as the drama. Lauren Bacall is drop-dead gorgeous and sexy as Vivian Rutledge, and her chemistry with Bogart is va-va-va-voom. Their dialogue, with those sexy innuendos and undertones, is one of the delights of this film, particularly when they're discussing horse racing. Mrs. Rutledge feels it all depends on "who's in the saddle." Fabulous. That scene and several others were added much later to benefit Bacall's character; Warners and her agent were afraid more bad reviews like she received in Confidential Agent would ruin her. (The fact that she was miscast in Confidential Agent seems to have escaped everyone.) According to Raymond Chandler, Martha Vickers overshadowed Bacall, so lots of her footage was cut.Bogart and Bacall made several films together, but I think this is their best. Bacall, admittedly nervous in "To Have and Have Not," though it didn't show, is supremely confident in this and gives as good as she gets.I just followed the story and attempted to keep track of it, all the while enjoying the repartee between these two. I usually don't think of Bogart as sexy, but he sure was here. Goes to show you what love can do.

reviews.review_title: Plot, schmlot - what a great movie this is!
reviews.content: To begin with, you have not seen this film until you have seen a mint print on a theater screen. The lighting effects here are astonishing, and when film fans decry 'colorization' and insist that a B&W film be seen in B&W, this is one of the films their talking about.the film is shot so that the center of the image is predominately light gray in tone, but harsh black shadows suddenly cut through the center and create multiple spaces, leaving a sense of three-dimensionality that is made uneasy by the sudden disruptions in light values.No 'noir' film ever quite caught the atmospherics that supposedly make the whole genre memorable as well as this one. Hawks knows the story is way overcomplicated - at one point in the writing of the script, Brackett and Faulkner realized they couldn't tell who killed the guy who was found in the car in the bay; they telephoned novelist Chandler, who, after a long pause for thought, admitted that he didn't know either! (The novel's worth - as with most of Chandler's best - derives from his ability to write paragraphs like poetry.) But Hawks was a director in love with challenges like this one; so he turned the whole film into an exercise in mood and character. Could the mood make the characters come alive? Could the actors take this opportunity to drive the plot despite the lapses and complications? Obviously, my answer is a strong "yes!" As a viewer, I become immersed in this other world that is so predominately night, and in learning all I can about these characters. And when the movie ends, I feel I have experienced something different yet wholly satisfying.Surely this is one of the greatest attractions and accomplishments of any film.

Humphrey Bogart made several films in the 1940s, which I saw on television when I was very young. Although I fully enjoyed the films back then; I expected to more fully comprehend them when I was older. Now, I am older, and, while I still enjoy films like "The Big Sleep", I do not expect there will ever be any way to understand the storyline of this one. Mr. Bogart is detective Philip Marlowe, hired by older General Sternwood (Charles Waldron) to solve an increasingly complicated crime. The aptly named Sternwood has two sexually charged daughters: Lauren Bacall (as Vivian) and Martha Vickers (as Carmen). And, check out young Dorothy Malone as a bookstore clerk.The pairing of Bogart and Ms Bacall is terrific; and, Ms. Vickers is no slouch, either. One of the best scenes involves Bacall unsuccessfully trying to ignore an itch under her dress; finally, Bogart invites her to scratch away. Such scenes have a great sexual energy, and innuendo. Although the story, as a whole, is too vague, the script is exceptional. It's full of wit. Raymond Chandler (original novelist), Leigh Brackett, William Faulkner, and Jules Furthman have written exceptional conversational dialogue. And, the film has a wonderful look; it's directed, with great style, by Howard Hawks. His Bogart/Bacall scenes are very entertaining, and the action sequences exciting; especially notable is the confrontation between Bogart and "Lundgren" (Tommy Rafferty). ******** The Big Sleep (8/23/46) Howard Hawks ~ Humphrey Bogart, Lauren Bacall, Martha Vickers

reviews.review_title: The Big Sleep is a crazy convoluted mess.
reviews.content: The Big Sleep is a convoluted mess that leaves you wondering, "What just happened?". Although the movie includes impeccable dialogue and incredible acting by Bogart (Marlowe) and Bacall (Vivian Reagan) with a strong supporting cast, the scenes move so quickly it may take several watches to figure what is happening. Many times the scenes move so quickly, and so many characters are introduced I was left completely confused. There were so many subplots and characters intricately connected, it was difficult to follow. Such as the scene where the Sternwood's chauffeur died, I still cannot pinpoint who killed him. Bogart, encapsulates Marlowe perfectly, and Bacall who plays Vivian Reagan is able to bring out a convincing performance. The rapid scenes and sudden actions by each character do not really leave any time to process what just happened. The movie does have an incredible score and sound effects, such as the gun shots. But, I was really not able to understand what was happening. Although the cast gives an incredible performance, I really could not understand all the points of the story. Overall the music works perfectly with each scene and the cast does an admirable job, the confusing plot cannot be ignored. Throughout the movie I was left extremely lost and that really detracted from my enjoyment of the movie.

With movies like "The Big Sleep" and "The Maltese Falcon", among others, private detective = Humphrey Bogart. No question. "The Big Sleep" has a complicated plot and it requires some effort to follow what you can of it - that's a good thing, because I like to engage my bran in a movie. However that aside, there's a lot here anyway to like.Bogart plays Marlowe, but he also plays Bogart. He brings himself to the role - the dry drawl, the sharp on-screen presence, the sheer assuredness of character. He plays well against Lauren Bacall, one of two daughters of the man - Stockwood - who hired him to find a missing friend. As the mysteries and confusion deepen, Bogart and Bacall constantly find their paths interweaving. They have great simmering chemistry on screen and display anger and passion towards one another - an interesting combination. Neither roles can be faulted much.The film moves along sharply - you're never left bored - thanks to Director Howard Hawks. He has the "film noir" feel done well, and there's a nice broody atmosphere to the picture, accompanied by a great score."The Big Sleep" is a movie well worth checking out. You may be confused by some plot turns, but that's a side issue when the production you're left with plays out so well. A fine 8/10.

reviews.review_title: It's All Style And It's All So Good
reviews.content: I'll be honest and admit that I haven't actually read the Chandler novel this was based upon.Maybe I should have. It could have helped me work out the complicated, mussy plot of 'The Big Sleep' better.But WHO CARES about plot when you have a super-stylish noir boasting shady, fascinating characters, Bogart and Bacall, a brilliant screenplay and a whole lot of humour. I know I'm breaking my 'law' that a good plot is vital to a good film, but 'The Big Sleep' is an exception to the rule. It doesn't seem to need a strong storyline, and it's classic status has endured without one. Chandler couldn't even explain many of the events in his novel, so how could the film be expected to?It is Martha Vickers that almost steals this movie, though. As the nymphomaniac, perpetually drugged-up Carmen Sternwood, younger sister to Bacall's Vivien, she is simply fantastic. Apparently many of her scenes were cut (!) because she was stealing the film from right under leading lady Lauren Bacall's nose. Bogart is perfect as usual as our favourite detective Phillip Marlowe.Lucky Bogart. Every female wants to jump him in this film, and who could blame them? He oozes sex appeal and charisma. No wonder Bacall fell for him. He again shares terrific chemistry with his soon-to-be wife. The feeling of equality and mutual need is there. Marlowe is not the cynical Spade we saw Bogart play in 'The Maltese Falcon' 5 years earlier. Marlowe is no push-over, but he does play the 'sap' for women occasionally. He's a much more likable fellow than the hardened Spade.Style, style, style. This film has it in bucket loads, from the sexy play between the sexes to the dark, rainy streets. It is certainly one of the greats of the noir genre, and one of the most charismatic.10/10.

reviews.review_title: This is an all time classic that is well written and well executed
reviews.content: The Big Sleep (1946) is a movie that I recently rewatched on HBOMAX. The storyline follows a private detective that has been hired by a wealthy family to uncover the details behind a black mail and find missing individuals with clues on who is responsible and why. The detective starts falling for one of the rich man's daughters but he isn't oblivious that she may be interested in him for her own ambitions. Can the detective weave through the charades to uncover what really happened and is behind the family's troubles?This movie is directed by Howard Hawks (Rio Bravo) and stars Humphrey Bogart (Key Largo), Lauren Bacall (Murder on the Orient Express), Martha Vickers (Alimony), John Ridgely (Arsenic and Old Lace) and Peggy Knudsen (Istanbul).The cast in this is absolutely tremendous and has great chemistry. The dialogue was outstanding and felt like a game of cat and mouse from beginning to end. The storyline has unpredictable twists and turns leading to a fantastic ending. There's a kiss scene and a rope sequence that are outstanding and the shootout at the end is tremendous.Overall, this is an all time classic that is well written and well executed. I would score this a 10/10 and strongly recommend it.

reviews.review_title: A Wonderful Production of a Mystery-Noir Classic Storyline; Outstanding
reviews.content: I must report that as good as this this classic film noir entry written by Leigh Brackett and others is as screen writing, it is still a bit overrated. Humphrey Bogart tries hard in the role of Philip Marlower, though he is not ideal for the part; and others such as John Ridgeley, Frank Puglia, very young Lauren Bacall and Dorothy Malone do very well indeed. Other parts are less-well realized. But what the viewer sees here is a convoluted storyline that is made to work technically and artistically by Howard Hawks, the skilled director, and by a more-than-attractive production made in glowing B/W, featuring a large number of well-mounted scenes. The original novel by Raymond Chandler was a pasting together of plot elements drawn from very fine earlier short stories; it is to be regretted that he did not later rewrite this early attempt which is quite unsatisfying compared to his later works. But the promising storyline was taken up by the screenwriters and made into a very memorable set of ethically contexted characters, the actions they feel compelled to take and their reactions to the consequences of those actions. The film has a lot of very famous tough and terse dialogue of course; but the dialogue is always used to move the slender plot-mystery along. The art direction and cinematography are unusually good in most places; many minor parts are played very well, by Elisha Cook Jr., Trevor Bardette, Charles D. Brown and others. Blocking of difficult-to-stage scenes is very good, such as a large nightclub-gambling joint, the action climax at a country house and the opening in General Sternwood's nicely-considered home where p.i. Marlowe first meets his potential client (Charles Waldon)and his two unruly daughters (particularly Bacall). One of the best elements of this bright film is the way pairs of persons play with one another and off a third person; perhaps no one can follow the storyline exactly, but there is hardly a dull second in this importantly-well-made adventure noir entry. No wonder this is the most copied of all early noir films, and one that in its own metier has never been equaled. We never miss a chance to enjoy this ground-breaking achievement.

reviews.review_title: Quintessential Noir with Insane Plot but Superb Atmosphere
reviews.content: Philip Marlowe, a Los Angeles private detective, is hired by the wealthy General Sternwood to discover why his younger daughter, Carmen, is being blackmailed and to find out what has happened to his former employee Sean Regan who has disappeared. Marlowe traces the blackmailer, Arthur Geiger, to his house, only to find that Geiger has been shot dead. Any further explanation of the plot would be difficult; from this point onwards it becomes very complex, with a large cast of characters being introduced and several more murders being committed, as Marlowe uncovers a web of corruption and violent crime. The plot is not only extraordinarily complicated, it is also confusing, containing threads that are never developed and events that are never explained. It is said that even the scriptwriter, the well-known novelist William Faulkner, did not know who committed one of the murders, nor the motive for which it was committed, and that Raymond Chandler, the author of the original novel on which the film was based, proved to be no more helpful. (Is it significant that the leading character has the same surname as the Elizabethan dramatist known for his complex and gruesome plots?)This is not, however, the sort of movie one watches primarily for the plot. Anyone who watches it expecting it to be an Agatha Christie type 'whodunit', with all the crimes solved and all loose ends neatly tidied up in the final scene is likely to be disappointed. What makes the film so watchable is its atmosphere. A dark, menacing feeling was a hallmark of the 'film noir' style, but in 'The Big Sleep' it is particularly strong. In keeping with the dark deeds that make up its plot, much of the action takes place either at night or against a background of torrential rain. Combined with this is an air of dubious glamour. There are numerous strikingly beautiful but sinister women among the cast, some of them only playing minor roles. The best-known of these is, of course, Lauren Bacall as Carmen's older sister Vivian (who provides Marlowe's love-interest), but there are also Martha Vickers as Carmen herself, Dorothy Malone, Peggy Knudsen, Sonia Darrin and Joy Barlow. (Joy Barlow? She is the angelic-looking brunette who plays the female tax-driver who appears in one brief scene. She had bit-parts in fourteen films in the 1940s, only being credited on one of them. Even in Hollywood, looks are not always enough to guarantee success). One might have expected the late forties, following the return of peace after the victorious conclusion to the Second World War, would have been a time of optimism in America, but this mood was not always reflected in the films of the era. This was the heyday of film noir, the most pessimistic of genres. As well as being physically dark, 'The Big Sleep' is also morally dark. The mood is one of cynicism and world-weariness, mostly emanating from Humphrey Bogart's interpretation of the lead character. This was the sort of part in which Bogart excelled; apart from 'Casablanca' (in which he played another type of cynic), he is probably best-remembered today for his film noir roles, especially the hard-bitten private eyes he played here and in 'The Maltese Falcon'. There is, of course, frequently a more human side beneath the surface Bogart cynicism; Rick in 'Casablanca' ends up 'doing the decent thing', and Marlowe, for all his cynical wit, has a genuine desire to see justice done. Bogart gave so many great performances in the course of his career that it would be difficult to single one out as being his best, but 'The Big Sleep' must come high on the list. Lauren Bacall, Bogart's real-life wife, is also excellent in this film, and there is a genuine sexual tension in the scenes between them. It is interesting that the film was completely overlooked by the Academy; it did not receive a single Oscar nomination. Like a number of other classic films noirs it seems to be more highly regarded now than when it was made. Despite the insane complexity of its plot, this is a film that never fails to hold the attention, and still has the power to fascinate nearly sixty years on. 8/10

The Big Sleep begins with a series of memorable, entertaining scenes. Even Bogart is a hoot donning a disguise and an altered voice at one point. Then scenes of equal weight and equal length begin piling up and it readily becomes apparent that the best stuff was in the first half hour when things still had potential. The 6th time Bogart drives to Geigers cottage you may be crying, "Enough!" but this plot just keeps going and going...I had been warned that this one was quite elaborate and it is. Something like seven people are dead and I still can't tell you why. The only noir where I lost interest in the plot quicker, was Murder My Sweet which was just as elaborately silly. Can't each cadaver have a walk-on before they're killed. (Owen Taylor and Sean Regan) I tend to confuse stiffs I've never seen. If it must be this complicated, couldn't the writers make the narrative/crime so compelling that a viewer is drawn in? How can a viewer care about a solution when they haven't seen (and haven't been made to care about) a crime that occurred before the movie even started?I accidentally viewed the wrong side of my double sided DVD and preferred the 1944 version to the one that audiences loved in 1946. I see very negligible differences in the two versions that saved it from Bacall's supposedly poor performance. Seems like the sexually-charged racehorse dialog needed inclusion because without it, the most emotionally involved Bogart gets with anyone is with the rare books girl. Without it, Bacall just simmers for the whole movie.The thing I find strange about noir is that even the most pricey production feels like it was shot on the cheap. Here, two or three major characters never appear, but are talked about and credited with driving the whole plot. Central characters are never visualized; to save money... or to allow the plot to be more complicated? Also cheap, but effective is that night looks a bit more like night in Bogart's movies because they skip the expensive exterior day-for-night shoots, which I never find convincing and always find distracting. (Why are people gleaming in the dark?)LA Confidetnial and Chinatown both make overtures to this.
Except for Humphrey Bogart, who expectedly nailed his role, this is just an average Film-Noir. It is considered one of the best movies of all time, but I honestly cannot understand why.6/10

reviews.review_title: Who me! I'm just the guy who does everyone else's laundry
reviews.content: ***MAJOR SPOILERS***Being hired by Gen. Sternwood to clear up some problems that his younger daughter Carman got herself into private investigator Philip Marlow feels that it will be just routine for him and nothing more. Carman has gotten herself into debt at what later turned out to be Eddie Mars gambling den and was being blackmailed by one of Mars tenant, in a house that he rented him, rare book-shop owner Arthur Geiger.Marlow checking out Geiger's place is shocked to hear this woman screaming and when he breaks in he finds Geiger shot dead and Carman in a state hysteria unable to talk as Geiger's killer, or killers, take off in two different automobiles. Finding Geiger's little black book with names of those whom, like Carman and her father Gen. Sternwood, he's blackmailing Marlow deduces that he may well have been murdered by one of the persons in that book. Marlow also notices that there's a hidden camera with the film missing and with Carmen scantily dressed it didn't take long for Marlow to realize that she was, with almost no clothes on, the one who was photographed.It's then that Marlow takes Carman back home and tells her older sister the former Mrs. Vivian Rutledge Sternwood to tell the police if they show up that she was at home the entire evening. This is Marlows way of keeping Carman from being suspected in Geigers murder. It's later when the Sternwood chauffeur Owen Taylor, whom Marlow finds out murdered Geiger,is found dead with a broken neck at the bottom of Lido Pier that things start to go a bit too fast in the movie and makes it almost impossible to figure just what Carmans real problems are. It turns out that Carmans troubles have really nothing to do with either being blackmailed for not paying off her gambling debts or being photographed in the nude; they have a lot to do with something far more serious murder.Dspite all the killings in the film, I counted seven of them,the one most on Gen. Sternwood's mind was that of his former employee Sean Regan. It's not until much later in the film that you begin to realize that it was Regan whom Gen. Sternwood was really interested in finding and using his young and somewhat unstable daughter Carman as a cover in having Marlow find him, dead or alive. Regan had become somewhat of a son to the old man and his sudden disappearance had deeply affected him. Gen. Sternwood was positive that Regan didn't just leave on his own but that something terrible happened to him and he also suspected Carman to have been the person who was responsible for it.Meanwhile Marlow is totally clueless to what's really on Gen. Sternwood's mind which the general did everything to throw Marlow off in having him find Regan by making it look like he was trying to uncover who was blackmailing him over his daughter Carman. During the film Marlow gets involved in a number of murders as well as having himself badly worked over by Mars hoods as well as falling in love with Gen. Sternwood's older daughter Vivian. Vivian herself knows that her younger sister was somehow involved in Regan's disappearance and you start to wonder if her relationship with Marlow was really on the up and up or she was only using him to get the cops from suspecting Carman in Regan's disappearance or even murder!The movie or Philip Marlow has non other then Eddie Mars get set up for Regan's murder in his already having been responsible for at least two others that of Owen Taylor and little Harry Jones as well as trying to have his hoods knock off Philip Marlow himself. Marlow with Vivian, who for a time was working with Mars, have Mars show up at the late Arthur Geigers place and trick him into having his boys outside think that Marlow was the first one to first step out the door. Firing at Mars and wounding him Marlow has him run for his life outside where his hoods, mistaking him for Marlow, blast him to pieces with the police who were alerted by Marlow, by phone from inside the house, coming on the scene to arrest them.With the dead Mars now being framed in Regan's, his body had since been found, murder Marlow with both Vivian's and Gen. Sternwood's help have Carman sent away to a mental institution where she can get help and at the same time not end up behind bars for Sean Regan's murder. The truth is that Carman not Eddie Mars was responsible for Regan's murder when he left her for Eddie's wife Mora which drove the very mentally and emotionally unstable Carman to go off the deep end and murder him.P.S The remake of "The Big Sleep" in 1978 with Robert Mitchum playing Philip Marlow had a lot more cohesive plot and didn't confuse those watching the movie like the 1946 version did. Even though the 1978 version covered the same ground as the original it stuck to the story and didn't hit you with side-plot after side-plot that by the time the movie was finally over you had no idea what you were watching for the last two or so hours on the screen.

reviews.review_title: Humphrey Bogart and Lauren Bacall in this great Film-noir, with a magnificent direction by Howard Hawks!
reviews.content: Bogart is really cinema's coolest star and he is both very good and very funny. The dialogue and the script by William Faulkner is superb(As you all know this film is based on the book by Raymond Chandler). The story is very complicated but who cares as long as it is so very entertaining. It is from 1946 and still it does not feel old, "Chinatown" must have been inspired a lot by this film! I would give it a 9/10

reviews.review_title: Classic film-noir, doesn't hold up very well
reviews.content: Saw the high score (8.1) on this film and decided to check it out. The plot sounded cool and I thought it must be a great film.I can see why this a classic and would have been popular at the time, but it honestly does not hold up very well to modern crime/mystery films. There is so much talking and exposition, so many character names to keep track of, and the story just didn't impress me all that much. The "plot twist" that are critical to any good crime mystery, just aren't that surprising and the film doesn't really feel like it builds to any kind of climax that I found myself caring out.There are some good performances in this film, but it is not something that I would want to watch again any time soon. I was bored through most of it, and I was having to work hard the whole time to pay attention to all the little details, trying to keep all the characters straight, hoping that it would pay off with some amazing ending, but that never really came. I think a lot of these old movies have very generous score on IMDb and this is one of them. Maybe it has a lot to do with nostalgia, or the importance of this film at the time it was made.Either way, if you are looking for an exciting crime murder mystery, I would look elsewhere. If you are into classic film noir movies, or a big fan of Bogart, then maybe this is the film for you.

reviews.review_title: They Don't Make 'Em Like This Anymore
reviews.content: After looking at some of the preceding reviews, there is not much more left to be said about this stylish dark detective thriller of the 40's. Who can fault the director, stars, author, or screenplay? All were top drawer in their field. Granted, the story is confusing with so many characters and sub-plots that you need a diagram to follow who is doing what to whom. And certainly violent enough......did you notice that Marlowe shoots Canino not once, but three times....and how about when he pushes Eddie Mars out the door to be shot down by his own men. No talking or beating around the bush here! How much more can be said about Bogart and Bacall?....to this day, their presence still evokes passion in their fans, me included. But there are a some other players in this film worth mentioning. Bob Steele, as Canino, is so perfect for the role of Mars' henchman,..he is truly evil and Steele plays it to a T. It is also strange to see John Ridgley playing a bad guy; he was usually the bland sidekick and his role as Eddie Mars is against type. It works. Elisha Cook Jr. is spot on as the pathetic "little man" Jonesy. And Dorothy Malone comes across (in more ways than one it appears)in her small part as the book store clerk, glasses and all. My favorite line from the film comes from Martha Vickers when she first meets Marlowe and says, "You're not very tall are you?".......Marlowe's reply,"I try to be." If you like fast moving, hard bitten films with great black and white cinematography, this is the ticket. It's a delight!

reviews.review_title: One of the best in Bogart's series of film-noir.
reviews.content: This is one of the best movies Bogart ever did in the film-noir genre and in my opinion is a very close second-best Bogart-Bacall picture, the first one being "Key Largo".What was one of the best parts of this movie is that Howard Hawks shifts you over from one bad-guy to another making you believe he's the killer or the blackmailer but upon hearing the man's story, you can only be sure that he might be guilty of one act but not of another.Philip Marlowe (Bogart) is summoned by colonel Sternwood to investigate on a certain unknown person who has been blackmailing him and the whole story suddenly becomes a murder investigation.  Naturally, Bogart runs into Lauren Bacall (probably in one of her better roles) and the two of them create this incredible love-hate-arrogance chemistry keeping you absolutely riveting.  Fans of Bogart-Bacall movies must see this one at all costs.

I try to imagine watching Howard Hawks's movie version of Raymond Chandler's "The Big Sleep" when it first got released. It was right after WWII had ended, and people were no doubt mired in optimism. If so, then movies like this may have existed to temper everyone's optimism.Eternal tough guy Humphrey Bogart, hot off the success of "The Maltese Falcon", "Casablanca" and "To Have and Have Not", plays private eye Philip Marlowe, surrounded by a murky, sleazy world of various cases. One day, he gets hired by an old man to investigate a case. Of course, he's about to get a lot more than he bargained for. Throughout the whole movie, you can feel the tension between the various characters, and you wonder who's hiding what. It goes to show that Bogie and Lauren Bacall were truly a great team.Oh, and by the way, I noticed that in one scene, Marlowe enters Acme Bookstore. Maybe that was just the name, but maybe there was more to it than that. I try to imagine Wile E. Coyote ordering from them some wacky device to try and trap Road Runner (only to fail, natch). Probably not many people interpret that, but I do.Anyway, a really good movie.

This is perhaps my favourite film, if there can be such a thing. It is certainly the best noir film.It involves Detective Phillip Marlowe (Humphrey Bogart) who is hired by a General Sternwood to find out who is blackmailing him over the activities of his youngest daughter. His investigation turns up a world of sleaze and murder.I have seen this film rated down because of the convoluted and confusing plot. That is one of the things I love about it, along with the snappy dialogue and sleazy subject matter that was very risque in the 40's.It has a host of interesting and entertaining characters, and is beautifully filmed in B&W.Every murder IS accounted for, along with the various motives. There is no need for me to explain who did what and why here as it is very clearly outlined in the imdb synopsis.Just sit back and enjoy the ride.

reviews.review_title: Delicious mystery; Bogie & Bacall's best together...
reviews.content: Humphrey Bogart is perfectly cast as Raymond Chandler's famous private-dick Philip Marlowe, here on blackmail/murder case involving two wealthy Los Angeles sisters. Plot is endlessly complicated, so don't even try to sort it all out (you'd need a blackboard and a big eraser). But why complain when the picture is so crafty and stylish, exotic, charming, and vivid. A slightly different version (the original cut, shot before Lauren Bacall's star-prominence) is often shown on the Turner Classics channel and features fewer scenes between Bogart and Bacall; it's also worth watching, but only after you've seen this re-shot version, with its suggestive dialogue and looser performances. *** from ****

"The Big Sleep" is a good movie that I have now viewed twice (once for a Film Theory course, once for pleasure). But, unlike a movie that is "very good" or "excellent," it runs out of steam well before its climax. It is a well-made film, that is for certain--director Howard Hawks choreographs every scene with fluid blocking and hard-boiled dialog that eventually becomes self-parodic. Adapted from a novel by Raymond Chandler, "The Big Sleep" is not the "masterpiece" that many claim--for comparative purposes, such neo-Noir as "Chinatown" (1974) and "L.A. Confidential" (1997) interweave many characters and plot threads more coherently, while still leaving enough ambiguity to warrant repeat viewings. "The Big Sleep" begins with a plot setup that will bob and weave freely over its two hours: a millionaire is being blackmailed, and private eye Philip Marlowe (Humphrey Bogart) is called in to get to the bottom of it. To watch the movie is to be in a state of utter confusion (indeed, even Chandler couldn't follow it), and even as I took notes, I still came up with a fair amount of unresolved loose ends. And the double-crosses and dead bodies that surface in the narrative become increasingly hard to care about, since the characters exist as types rather than fleshed-out individuals. Ultimately, the best reasons to watch "The Big Sleep" have nothing to do with the plot--Bogart is well-cast as the quick-witted Marlowe, and Lauren Bacall (who was married to Bogart at the time) makes a fitting--albeit ice-cold--femme fatale, and Hawks skillfully directs a screenplay that seems confusing for its own sake. The film is not bad, but it could have been a whole lot better.

Big Sleep, The (1946) (Theatrical version) **** (out of 4) Classic film has private detective Philip Marlowe (Humphrey Bogart) getting involved with a rich family who seems to be getting blackmailed over some photos of the youngest sister. Soon the detective is in over his head with the older sister (Lauren Bacall) who might know more than she's telling. It's hard to believe that one of the greatest films of the decade also has what is perhaps the worst story. I believe this was my third time watching this and the story doesn't make any more sense now than it did the first couple of times I watched it. It's rather amazing at how highly thought of this film is even with its lack of a coherent story to follow. You'd really think a weak plot would lead to a weak film but that's far from the case because this here is certainly a pure classic of the genre. What works so well are the incredible performances mixed with the strong direction. Bogart is once again playing a cool but tough detective and God knows no one was ever better than he was. I often wonder if Bogart got a kick out of practicing his various walks for these types of films because he certainly nails it each time he walks into a room to knock out a bad guy or just flirt with a woman. His calm and cool nature really makes for a great leading man and he makes the role his own. Bacall also turns in another winning performance but it's Martha Vickers as her younger sister who really steals the show. John Ridgely, Dorothy Malone and Regis Toomey add great support as well. If you discuss this film the rather strange plot often gets talked about but I think the reason people overlook this is because the heart of the film isn't with solving the case but with the fun behind trying to solve it. The end result really doesn't matter because the viewer, as well as the characters, are having fun going through all the trouble of trying to come up with clues, villains and the reasons behind everything. A lot of the credit for this certainly goes to Hawks whose direction is solid and never wavers any of his style or vision.

reviews.review_title: Classic noir with some of the greatest lines
reviews.content: Husband and wife Humphrey Bogart and Lauren Bacall make another classic. He's private eye Philip Marlowe hired by rich widower General Sternwood who is being blackmailed. One year ago, he paid Joe Brody $5000 to leave his youngest daughter wild Carmen (Martha Vickers) alone. His other daughter Vivian Rutledge (Bacall) has left her husband. Both daughters are living with him. Now Carmen has signed notes for some gambling debts and Marlowe recommends paying the debts off. His investigations gets more and more complicated.This is fast-talking incredibly complicated double-crossing noir classic. Lines don't get better than "She tried to sit in my lap, while I was standing up." or "I collect blondes and bottles, too." The story is a bit too complicated to keep attached to. It's like a bucking bronco who keeps trying to throw you off. However the great lines keep coming and that's what so great about the movie.

Along with the original (Dick Powell) version of Farewell, My Lovely this initial adaptation of The Big Sleep is light years ahead of subsequent adaptations of Chandler novels - and it's highly debatable if the Michael Winner travesty of The Big Sleep should even be included in the set. Only those who have read and delighted in the book would perhaps take exception to the changes, not all of which can be excused on grounds of censorship - for example in the book the elder Sternwood daughter had been married to Sean Regan and Marlow learned at first hand that Carmen had shot Regan when she tries the same stunt on him - whilst viewers who lack the comparison will find much to enjoy in the crisp writing, directing and acting. Too much has been written already here for me to need to replicate it so suffice it to say that this movie's reputation as a Classic is well deserved.

The theatrical cut is a classic but the original pre-release cut on the flipside of the DVD is well worth watching. If you've ever wondered what on earth is going on in the plot this recently recovered version may help clarify things. As usual you don't get it on the region 2 (European) release so this is another region 1 (US/Canada) DVD worth importing if you live in the UK. I'm not reviewing the film itself as there are plenty of reviews of the film here, suffice to say it's great and well deserves its status as a true classic of the film noir genre.

reviews.review_title: Forgettable Showcase for Bogie and Bacall
